sentences.sentence: The Young King
It was night, and the young King was sitting alone in a beautiful room of his palace.
His servants had all left him, and although he was alone, he did not feel lonely.
He was happy to have time to himself to think, because the next day was his coronation( 加冕 ) ceremony( 典礼 ), and he had many things to think about.
The young King was only sixteen years old, still just a young man.
He was the child of the old King’s only daughter, and when she had been just a young Princess( 公主 ), she had fallen in love with a mysterious( 神秘的 ) stranger.
Some people said this mysterious( 神秘的 ) stranger was a musician, and that he had made the Princess( 公主 ) love him by the magic of his beautiful music, although nobody knew for sure.
No matter what the truth may have been, the old King would not let the young Princess( 公主 ) marry this man, because he had wanted the young Princess( 公主 ) to marry a young Prince( 王子 ).
So the young Princess( 公主 ) ran away from the palace, and married the mysterious( 神秘的 ) man in secret.
Nine months later, she gave birth to( 生下 ) the young King.
When the young King was only a week old, some men stole him away from his mother’s side while she slept.
They took him to a place deep inside the forest, more than a day’s ride away from the palace.
There they gave the young King to a poor shepherd( 牧羊人 ) and his wife, who did not have any children of their own.
When the young Princess( 公主 ) woke up( 醒来 ), and found that her baby was gone, she died from( 死于 ) heartbreak, although some people thought she might have been poisoned( 被下毒 ).
The Princess( 公主 ) was buried( 被埋葬 ) in a small graveyard( 墓地 ) in the countryside, far away from the gates of the palace.
It is said that she was buried( 被埋葬 ) next to a handsome young man, and that when he was put in the ground, there was a knife sticking out of( 穿出 ) his chest( 胸膛 ).
No matter what the true story might have been, it is at least certain that the old King, just before his death, had ordered his servants to bring him his grandson.
Perhaps the old King did this because he felt bad about what he had done, or perhaps because he felt he had no choice, since he had no other children and only one grandson.
When his servants brought the boy to the palace, the old King named his grandson as the new King, and soon after that the old King died.
From the moment he first came to the palace, the young King seemed to be completely fascinated( 着迷的 ) with beautiful and precious( 珍奇的 ) things.
The servants who brought him to the palace often spoke of the cry of pleasure he gave when he first entered his new bedroom.
When he first saw the fine new clothes and jewels( 珠宝 ) which were now his, he took off his poor shepherd( 牧羊人 )’s clothing in an instant( 瞬间 ).
It is true that he did miss the freedom of his life in the forest, especially when he had to sit through the long and boring ceremonies( 典礼 ) which took up so much of each day.
But as soon as the ceremonies( 典礼 ) ended, the young King would run through his palace, and look with pleasure at every beautiful thing.
When taking these journeys of discovery, as the young King called them, he was often alone.
But stories began to be told around the palace of some strange things which the young King had been seen doing.
One of the palace servants claimed they had seen the young King on his knees in front of a painting, looking almost as if he were praying( 祈祷 ) to it.
On another occasion the young King had gone missing for several hours, and it was said that when he was found, he had been kissing one of the palace statues( 雕像 ).
It was obvious that the young King was truly a lover of beauty, but perhaps, some people thought, a little too much so.
